Name: Linear Programming
Description: Optimize a linear objective function subject to linear equality and inequality constraints. The decision variables are continuous.
Solvability: Easy (Polynomial time). Highly efficient solvers exist.

Name: Mixed-Integer Linear Programming
Description: An LP problem where some decision variables are constrained to be integers. This adds combinatorial complexity.
Solvability: Hard (NP-Hard). Solution time can grow exponentially
Example: but modern solvers are very powerful.

Name: Convex Optimization
Description: A broad class of problems where the objective function is convex and the constraint set is a convex set. Local minima are global minima.

Name: Quadratic Programming
Description: Optimize a quadratic objective function subject to linear constraints. A subclass of Convex Optimization if the Hessian is PSD.
Solvability: Easy (Polynomial time) if convex. Harder if non-convex.

Name: Nonlinear Programming
Description: Optimize a nonlinear objective function subject to nonlinear constraints. The most general form.
Solvability: Very Hard. No universal efficient algorithm. Solutions are often local

Name: Constraint Programming
Description: A paradigm for solving combinatorial problems by defining constraints between variables. Focuses on feasibility and logical constraints.
Solvability: Powerful for feasibility and highly combinatorial problems with specific constraint types.

Name: Stochastic Programming
Description: Optimization under uncertainty. Parameters are modeled using random variables with known probability distributions.
Solvability: Very Challenging. Problems often become extremely large when scenarios are enumerated.

Name: Robust Optimization
Description: Optimization under bounded uncertainty. Seeks solutions that are feasible for all realizations of the uncertain data within a defined set.
Example: but often tractable. Leads to deterministic

Name: Dynamic Programming
Description: A method for solving complex problems by breaking them down into simpler subproblems. It is both a modeling and solution paradigm.
Solvability: Varies. Can be efficient for problems with optimal substructure
Example: but can suffer from the "curse of dimensionality".

Name: Multi-Objective Optimization
Example: objective functions. There is no single optimal solution
Appearances: but a set of Pareto-optimal solutions.
column8: Challenging. Requires specialized algorithms to approximate the Pareto front.
